spans.span: exploration activities undertaken by sandfire resources limited (sandfire) on the murchison combined reporting group (c 35/2015) between the first grant date of 19 june 2014 and the final surrender date of all tenements, 22 november 2023 (the reporting period)
the exploration licences overlie favourable stratigraphy within the mineral-rich bryah basin
considered to be prospective for volcanogenic massive-sulfide (vms)-style cu-au-ag mineralisation

the murchison project (the project) is located approximately 70 to 90 km north to nne of meekatharra, 20 to 40 km south to southwest of the historical peak hill copper and gold mining centre, and 70 to 90 km southwest of sandfire’s degrussa cu-au mine
access to the project is via the great northern highway, ashburton downs- meekatharra road or the meekatharra-mount clare road, then by pastoral tracks
on 4 april 2022 a partial relinquishment of 14 graticule blocks on e 52/3330 was registered with dmirs
a total of 21 blocks remained
an outright surrender of exploration licences 51/1647, 51/1672, 51/1673, 51/1702, 51/1759, 51/1805, 51/1967, 51/1968, 52/2880, 52/2881 and 52/3330 was registered with dmirs on 22 november 2023
the lessees of mt padbury pastoral lease, brian garrity, james harvey nichols and william robert nichols, were advised of the relevant grants
e 52/3330 which is located within the nharnuwangga wajarri ngarlawangga native title determination
an alternative standard heritage agreement was negotiated with the wajarri yamatji native title claim during the application process
sandfire maintains an existing claim-wide settlement deed and heritage agreement with the nharnuwangga wajarri ngarlawangga native title determination
heritage surveys were undertaken during 2018 and 2019
the murchison project tenements are underlain by the lower proterozoic volcanic sedimentary basin sequence previously known as the glengarry group (gee, 1987), deposited on archaean basement
the pull-apart (proto-oceanic) basin into which these formations were deposited was controlled by major basement strike-slip faults
created a complex array of horsts and grabens

in mapping of the peak hill 1:250,000 sheet the geological survey of western australia (gswa) described the karalundi formation as a mixed clastic-carbonate, chert-tuff sequence, lying conformably between the doolgunna arkose and the narracoota volcanics in the southern part of the bryah basin, that represents a transition from a shallow-water marine environment to a rift environment, and the commencement of basalt volcanism
the narracoota formation conformably overlies the karalundi formation in the type area, which is specified as the mikhaburra-cashman area, 10-15 km south of narracoota homestead (gee, 1978)
the narracoota formation is the volcanic component of the bryah basin sequence
hynes and gee (1986) reported on the petrochemistry and tectonic setting of the narracoota metabasaltic rocks

they concluded that they have fairly uniform chemistry and are of mid-ocean-ridge basalt (morb) affinity, although the original mafic volcanic rocks may have been emplaced through the rifting of continental crust
noted were the presence of ultramafic members (high-mg basalts and komatiite)
they are hosted close to the base of a volcano-sedimentary facies and closely spatially related to faults
epigenetic gold deposits formed later in the tectonic evolution
are related to structures and reactivated faults
these are not stratigraphically controlled, but are a combination of structural and lithological control
the project area lies near the southern margin of the bryah basin sequence, where it is in faulted contact with the yerrida basin sequence

from the detailed gswa 1:100,000 scale mapping, the karalundi formation includes chert, siltstone, calcareous siltstone, cross-bedded and ferruginous arenite, litharenite, purple, green, and black shale, and minor quartz-pebble conglomerate lenses
the narracoota formation conformably overlies and locally interfingers with the karalundi formation
can be subdivided on texture, geochemistry, and petrology, into mafic schist, ultramafic schist, and basaltic hyaloclastite
the first two lithotypes are characterised by a pervasive schistosity, and the distinction between mafic and ultramafic composition can only be ascertained geochemically

the mafic-ultramafic schist includes actinolite-tremolite schist and chlorite schist. metadolerite dykes and sills, metabasaltic breccia, and minor metapyroxenite lenses are contained within the schists, and although these rocks are not internally deformed, they are included in the schist lithotype
within the mafic-ultramafic schist, good exposures of variably deformed pillowed meta-basalt (ean) may be observed
pods and lenses of jasperoidal chert are, in places, associated with the volcanic rocks, and they may represent hot spring chemical precipitates (eanc)
the metabasaltic hyaloclastites (eanh) are undeformed, dominantly of mafic composition, and have a spilitic character. both formations are overlain by cainozoic alluvium and colluvium cover sediments
a significant number of companies have undertaken exploration activities in and around the project area, from the late 1970’s until the present day
since the mid-1980s this exploration has been focussed primarily on base metals, primarily copper, and gold

within the 2016-17 reporting period sandfire commissioned new resolution geophysics (nrg) to fly a 200 m spaced heliborne electromagnetic (em) survey across several areas, including a portion of e 51/1672
the operations report is attached in appendix 1

during the 2017-18 reporting period sandfire commissioned a detailed airborne magnetic survey (registration #71385) covering a portion of the prospective bryah stratigraphy, including the entire murchison combined reporting group
the extent of the survey is shown in figure 6.6
imagery is presented in figure 6.7
the operations report is attached in appendix 1
the magnetic imagery added significantly to the geological understanding of the area

a portion of the murchison project was covered by a regional-scale bryah basin ground gravity survey during the 2018-19 reporting period. the survey was undertaken by atlas geophysics under the direction of newexco services pty ltd
the gravity data provided a far greater level of resolution to existing data
added significant value to the understanding of the area
gravity data and reports are included in appendix 2
the eastern titles of the murchison project (e 51/1647 and e 51/1672) were covered by a basin-scale moving loop electromagnetic (mlem) survey between 2019 and 2020
the mlem logistics report is included in appendix 3
19 rock chip samples were collected from available outcrop

rock chips were analysed by icp-ms (inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry) and icp-es (inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry) after aqua regia digest by bureau veritas minerals (formerly ultratrace) in perth
returned no significant copper or gold anomalism
location and assay data are attached in appendix 4
drilling was conducted across several titles as part of a broader ‘enterprise farm-in’ exploration project
drilling aimed to identify prospective stratigraphy in the interpreted location of the karalundi and naracoota formations, and to provide quality geochemical information across the area
drilling locations are shown in figure 6.10
drilling and assay data are attached in appendix 4
between august 2017 and april 2019 sandfire drilled 521 air core (ac) holes (for a total of 35,425 m) over e 51/1647, e 51/1672 and e 51/1673
drilling was intended to identify prospective stratigraphy, and to infill across the prospective lithologies to determine geochemistry and identify anomalies
this was complicated in the area
the possible presence of outliers of the earaheedy group mount leake formation, which unconformably overlies the prospective bryah group

lithologies intersected included sandstone and siltstone of the doolgunna formation, sedimentary breccia and conglomerate, siltstone and sandstone, lithic wacke, mafic-derived breccia, minor chert and jaspilite, dolerite and basalt of the karalundi formation, and narracoota formation basalt
no significant anomalism was detected
the ac drilling shows end-of-hole lithologies of two broad types; a mafic volcano-sedimentary sequence (karalundi fm), and a more massive basalt package (naracoota fm)
this broadly matches the regional interpretation
clearly correlates to the airborne magnetic imagery
a moderate, short wavelength mid to late time response was detected
relating to a moderate magnetic response extending off-hole
dhem data and reports are included in appendix 5
between april and november 2019 sandfire drilled 336 ac holes (for a total of 28,732 m) over e 51/1702, e 51/1759, e 52/2880 and e 52/2881
drilling intersected significant tholeiitic and high-magnesium basalts, with lesser siltstone, quartz arenite and black shale
interpreted to be of the narracoota formation
the mafic units intersected were interpreted to be of the narracoota formation, however this was questioned
the variability of geology intersected
